title: summer-reads-2019-the-20-best-beach-and-holiday-books
story: Conviction by Denise Mina Anna McDonald is obsessed with true crime podcasts. When her husband Hamish, suitcase in hand, announces he is leaving Anna for her best friend Estelle and taking their two daughters with them, her safe and predictable world implodes.That isnt even the strangest thing to happen to Anna on this particular November morning in Glasgow. Distracting herself with a new podcast ndash a yacht that mysteriously sunk in the Mediterranean with multiple deaths ndash she realises that one of the victims is from her secret past.Determined to unpick the murky events that led to his death, Anna embarks on a heady and dangerous adventure through the Highlands, glitzy south of France on to Venice and Paris. A whip-smart and galloping read.Someone We Know by Shari Lapena How well do any of us know our neighbours  Its a thorny question, one which Shari Lapena ndash who has carved a reputation for serving up top-notch domestic suspense thrillers ndash brings to le with unsettling effect.In a leafy, tight-knit neighbourhood an anonymous note is doing the rounds about a teenage boy who has been breaking into houses and snooping for fun. It appears innocuous enough but when a missing woman is found murdered, things crank up a notch.As secret ties and illicit liaisons with the dead woman begin to surface with devastating effect, three couples face having their lives turned upside. What s will each go to when it comes to protecting their seemingly picture-perfect lives  A fast-paced plot packed with delicious twists.The Poison Garden by Alex Marwood As the sole adult survivor of a mass suicide among the cult in which she was raised, Romy finds herself in unfamiliar territory: alone and outside the walls of the only community she has ever known.Survival takes on new meaning as she fights to keep herself and the le of her unborn child safe in a strange and dangerous new world. Who can Romy trust and who must she fear  And what horrors has she herself buried deep inside Buckle up and prepare to embark upon a dark, unnerving and helter-skelter journey. The Poison Garden is a captivating read that will stay with you long after you have closed its pages.The Body Lies by Jo Baker A young author-turned-English literature professor escapes London for a university post, seeking a fresh start away from the scene of a violent assault that upended her world.She immerses herself in the rigours of academic le and single motherhood. Yet the remote countryside isnt quite the haven she had hoped, not least when a troubled student begins submitting chapters from a novel that blurs the lines between fiction and reality.When the professor recognises herself as the ill-fated character in the book, a spine-tingling game of cat and mouse ensues. The Body Lies is a shrewdly layered thriller that unflinchingly tackles the quagmire of pressure, judgement and ever-present danger women navigate in their daily lives.BEST FOR hellip SALVING THE SOULSweet Sorrow by David Nicholls David Nicholls, author of Starter For Ten and One Day, is a master of the bittersweet coming-of-age novel. He has a canny knack for capturing joy and angst, the tumultuous pain of friendship and unabashedly championing the downtrodden and awkward souls among us.Sweet Sorrow is the story of a le-changing summer for -year-old Charlie Lewis. At the outset, things are unbearably bleak. Charlies exams didnt go too well and his days bear the heavy burden of a father locked in the grip of depression.Fran Fisher breezes into his world and, for the first time in a long while, Charlie feels hope. To win her heart, he must change everything about himself, not least joining a drama society and risking the ire of his friends, all while treading a poignant and precarious path towards adulthood.After The End by Clare Mackintosh You may be familiar with Clare Mackintosh, the former police officer-turned-author who has penned a clutch of clever psychological thrillers such as I Let You Go, I See You and Let Me Lie.Her latest novel is a marked departure from that genre yet every bit as compelling. It centres on Max and Pip, devoted parents who, when their young son Dylan is diagnosed with a brain tumour, face an unenviable and impossible choice ndash and they cant agree.With echoes of Me Before You and My Sisters Keeper, After The End is a tender, immersive and thought-provoking read. Mackintosh has written from the heart: in , she and her husband had to decide whether to keep their critically ill son alive or remove his le support.:Sir Paul McCartney on his late we Lindas photography ahead of Glasgow exhibitionThe Ten Loves Of Mr Nishino by Hiromi Kawakami The enigmatic Mr Nishino is a man who is incorrigible, seductive, elusive, and fickle. Or so we learn as this intriguing tale unfolds, told from the perspective of the many women ndash a colleague, a chance encounter, the daughter of his one true love ndash who have found their lives intertwined with his.It is a story of desire, envy, romantic mishap, star-crossed lovers, passion, courtship, infidelity, unrequited love and loneliness. Yet, rather than slavish devotion to an adored-but-unobtainable man, what emerges is a portrait of a man who is, at times, a slave to his own flaws.Written by Hiromi Kawakami, the award-winning author of Strange Weather In Tokyo and The Nakano Thrt Shop, and translated by Allison Markin Powell, it is published by Granta Books which brought us the brilliant Convenience Store Woman which featured in last years Summer Reads.BEST FOR hellip THE BEACH BAGThe Other Mrs Miller by Allison Dickson Phoebe Miller doesnt venture out much, preferring to stay within the confines of the home she shares with an increasingly distant husband. Her days are spent idling by the pool, staving off boredom through a fug of wine and ice cream.When a battered-looking blue car keeps showing up on her quiet cul-de-sac, she has an uneasy feeling the occupant may be watching her. But has no idea why. A welcome distraction arrives when a new family moves in across the street.Bubbly and fun-loving neighbour Vicki and her handsome college-bound son Jake each provide much-needed companionship for Phoebe. But at what cost  A twisty suspense novel that will keep you guessing until its final pages.Jailbirds: Lessons From A Womens Prison by Mim Skinner Mim Skinner spent three years working as an art teacher in a womens prison. If you want, she can reel off the statistics regarding re-offenders, suicide and jarring figures on how many of those incarcerated have been victims of more serious crime than those theyve committed.What makes Jailbirds so compelling, however, is the human stories of prison le. Like the woman who sneaked scissors from the classroom, not to stab a cellmate, but to give her pubic hair a quick trim in the toilet cubicle. Or three uses for coffee whitener: cheesecake, bread topper and glue.Skinners warmth and empathy radiates from the pages in this eye-opening read. Humbling, hopeful and wryly hilarious in equal measure, it serves as a powerful reminder about the importance that womens voices ndash even behind bars ndash deserve to be heard.Stay Sexy  Dont Get Murdered by Georgia Hardstark and Karen Kilgarf If youre not familiar with their work ndash err, where have you been  ndash Georgia Hardstark and Karen Kilgarf host the hugely popular true crime comedy podcast, My Favourite Murder, swapping gory tales as their  million listeners worldwide, aka "murderinos", avidly tune in.Stay Sexy  Dont Get Murdered ndash which takes its title from their podcast sign-off ndash is an interesting hybrid format, part joint autobiography, part self-help manual, which draws on their le experiences including struggles with depression, eating disorders and addiction.The duo ndash who bonded over a shared love of true crime documentary The Staircase at a Halloween party ndash cover themes such as "Karens Plan for When the Partys Finally Over" and "Georgias Top Ten Holy Sh*t! Moments in Therapy".BEST FOR hellip SPORTIn Sunshine Or In Shadow: How Boxing Brought Hope In The Troubles by Donald McRae A golden era of boxing in Ulster ndash one punctuated with names such as Barry McGuigan, Davy Larmour, Charlie Nash and Hugh Russell ndash is deftly captured by Donald McRae in a remarkable tale of hope and redemption.At its heart is a gym in the New Lodge area of Belfast, right on the frontline of the sectarian ide, where Gerry Storeys Holy Family Boxing Club became a place that the Protestant and Catholic communities could come together through a shared love of the sport.Despite widespread support, Storey still found himself the target of bomb attacks from those opposed to reconciliation. McRae follows Storey on his journeys to the Maze prison, where the trainer worked with prisoners serving le sentences from both Loyalist and Republican groups.Magic Spanner: The World Of Cycling According To Carlton Kirby Sport, pound.Cycling fans will likely be familiar with the high-octane and excitable tones of Carlton Kirby. The Eurosport commentator purveys a frank and forthright, albeit slightly, err, wandering commentary style as he relays the action from the Tour de France, Giro dItalia and Vuelta a Espana.In Magic Spanner, Kirby pulls back the curtain to reveal behind-the-scenes antics from cyclings Grand Tours, laying bare the hilarious, leftfield and downright bizarre moments that covering the sport brings, alongside oodles of expert analysis and witty anecdotes.Think over-exuberant fans in lime green mankinis displaying "jiggling hirsute buttocks", the etiquette of "comfort breaks" and a tongue-in-cheek guide to "the dark side of cycling" from hair and helicopter "doping" to the sticky bottle and that famed magic spanner.BEST FOR hellip ESCAPISMNoel Streatfeilds Holiday Stories by Noel Streatfeild This heart-warming collection of stories will stoke nostalgia for holidays from bygone years with tales of crime-solving adventures, unlikely friendships and fun-filled afternoons spent berry-picking, fly-fishing and decamped to the homes of doting grandparents.Noel Streatfeild began writing childrens books in  after working in munitions factories and canteens during the First World War and later as an actor. She is the author of the beloved classic Ballet Shoes and delightful books about skating, circuses and stage le.Holiday Stories follows on from a Christmas anthology published last year drawn from a series of forgotten stories only recently re-discovered among the late writers papers. Originally written for annuals and magazines between the s and s, they will appeal to readers of all ages.:Sir Paul McCartney on his late we Lindas photography ahead of Glasgow exhibitionThe Most Fun We Ever Had by Claire Lombardo Claire Lombardos impressive debut novel centres on a family with skeletons about to come rattling out of the closet. David and Marilyn Sorenson fell in love in the s, their relationship described as "two people who emanated more love than it seemed like the universe would sanction."The story shts back and forth in time as David and Marilyn raise their four markedly dferent daughters, Wendy, Violet, Liza and Grace, in the Chicago suburbs. As Liza puts it: "Its a vast hormonal hellscape. A marathon of instability and hair products."When a teenage boy given up for adoption  years earlier reappears into their lives, it throws open a Pandoras box filled with decades-old secrets and betrayals.Something To Live For by Richard Roper When you are surrounded by death it can be easy to forget how to live. Thats the fate that befalls Andrew, a council worker who spends his days searching for next of kin and attending the funerals of the deceased who dont have any traceable friends or family.On the surface, Andrew leads a happy le with the perfect we and . children waiting for him at home. The reality couldnt be starker. And now its time to change that.Inspired by the work of real-le council workers who deal with arranging funerals for those in our society who have slipped through the cracks and die alone, Richard Ropers debut is heart-breaking, uplting, funny and brimming with human kindness.BEST FOR hellip MEMOIRJust Another Mountain by Sarah Jane Douglas Sarah Jane Douglas was  when she lost her mother to breast cancer in . She vowed to honour a promise made to her late mother and keep going in the face of adversity.Douglas sought solace in the formidable mountains of her native Scotland. By walking in her mothers footsteps, she was able shed the cloak of grief and make peace with a troubled past, while garnering the much-needed strength to carry on in the face of her own diagnosis  years later.Honest, raw and beautully written, this uplting memoir is testament that in le there are times when there is nothing for it but to scale that mountain and often, despite your worst fears, the view from the top isnt half bad.Close To Where The Heart Gives Out by Malcolm Alexander Malcolm Alexander upped sticks and moved with his family from suburban Glasgow to the wilds of Orkney to become the resident GP on the island of Eday.They prepared "for an adventure that none of us really understood," he writes. "The haunting dference between working with a hospital, ambulances, colleagues all nearby, and working alone on an island with only a tenuous plane link to anywhere in an emergency."That was the job on paper. Yet, as this fascinating memoir reveals, there was far more to it than that as he treated a steady stream of eclectic ailments and the occasional non-human patient, including a stricken harbour seal. An ode to island le in all its glorious foibles and heart-soaring delights.Lowborn by Kerry Hudson Kerry Hudson visited the towns of her childhood to retrace her past and examine what it means to be poor in Britain today. The result was a Lowborn, a searing memoir which lays bare the dehumanising effects of poverty.Hudson started le in Aberdeen but was uprooted time and againto Canterbury, Airdrie, North Shields, Coatbridge and Great Yarmouth.Her mother struggled with depression. Her father was American and mostly absent. Hudson bears the scars of adverse childhood experiences carried into adulthood: emergency foster care, a sexual abuse child protection inquiry, rape and two abortions.But it is also a story about resilience. "These stories need to be told because society wishes to look in the other direction," writes Hudson. Dont look away, read this book.BEST FOR hellip LIFE LAUNDRYEverything Is F*cked: A Book About Hope by Mark Manson What do you need when it feels like the world is going to hell in a handbasket  A hefty dose of pragmatic advice. Step forward Mark Manson whose previous book The Subtle Art of Not Giving A F***saw him take on the mantle as anti-hero of pop psychology."We are a culture in need not of peace or prosperity or new hood ornaments for our electric cars," he writes in latest offering Everything Is F*cked. "We have all that. We are a culture in need of something far more precarious." That ever elusive totem  Hope.Manson rails against what he describes as "this couch-potato-pundit era of tweetstorms and outrage porn" and suggests there are other ways we can connect with the world around us. Provocative and no-holds-barred, it might just make you stop and take stock.:Sir Paul McCartney on his late we Lindas photography ahead of Glasgow exhibitionLet That Sh*t Go by Nina Purewal and Kate Petriw Yup, its another one with a swear word in the title. Do bear with me. Especiallyyou can relate to having an ever-growing to-do list, a perpetual guilty feeling about not spending enough time with loved ones or a nagging existential dread about a big deadline looming at work.Le is stressful but is doesnt have to be, according to Nina Purewal and Kate Petriw. The answer  Mindfulness. Granted, it has been a buzzword for a few years now, but ironically many of us are too busy or bogged down in mundanities to give it a whirl.Let That Sh*t Go features more than  tips on how to incorporate mindfulness into our everyday lives, stealing moments of much-needed calm amid the chaos. If you are prone to deluding yourself on a regular basis that "next week will be better", then this is the book to pack in your beach bag.

title: in-pictures-forth-bridge-visitor-experience-unveiled
story: The proposals centre on a ft high viewing .The hair-raising plans are expected to lead to , visitors a year coming to climb the structure which will reach its th anniversary in .:-year plan to boost tourism around Forth bridgesNetwork Rail is wants to take visitors onto the bridge on a regular basis for the first time, focussing on the "bridge climb" experience in South Queensferry.Access is envisaged to be provided via an existing walkway under the south approach span and a new steel walkway positioned discreetly within the top member of the southern suspended span.Visitors will move in groups of up to  from a new hub building near Hawes Brae and will be hooked on to the bridge using a harness and continuous safety line.A Network Rail spokesman said: "Our plans for the Forth Bridge Experience are progressing well and we look forward to being able to open up this iconic structure to the public."The initial plans for consultation with the community were approved by planners at Edinburgh City Council.It has been suggested a detailed application will be submitted this summer.

title: prince-charles-dumfries-house-project-reaching-beyond-estate-walls-to-revitalise-former-mining-town-new-cumnock
story: Mary remembers what it was like for visitors to the only freshwater open air pool in Scotland. She worked there until  when the council made  per cent of the two remaining staff redundant.ldquoThe curtains would stick to you when you were changing. There was only one toilet, a hole in the floor, the  year old recalls. She doesnrsquot mean a continental-style public loo. There was an actual hole in the floor.Three years ago things were bleak in New Cumnock. Since the decline of coal mining, the townrsquos population had shrunk from a high of , to around ,. Three years earlier it had been given a ldquocarbuncle when Urban Realm magazine dubbed it Scotlandrsquos most dismal town. Perhaps the final straw was the announcement that the Town Hall too would be closed. But the locals had one last play to make.They appealed to the Duke of Rothesay, Prince Charles. In the summer of  he had bought nearby Dumfries House for pound million and spent five years restoring it, opening the house itself, with its near-priceless collection of Chippendale Furniture to the public, and turning the grounds into an engine of regeneration.It is a remarkable project. Dumfries House offers training, education, artistic and health resources, for free, to those who can benefit. That includes craftspeople looking to learn traditional skills such as thatching, stone masonry and pargeting . It includes inspiring primary school children in science and engineering. Or giving people with diabetes the confidence to prepare healthier food.People like  year old Graeme Bone, of Auchinlea who took a college qualication in textiles and after a course at Dumfries House and now works upcycling factory offcuts to make bags and other items for sale at premium prices. Of those who do the course he did,  per cent find work. ldquoItrsquos hard not to be inspired here, he says.There is Gemma Kennedy, , also of Auchinleck, who got a weekend job in the cafe while still at school. She still works there, but also caters weddings and official dinners when the Prince is in residence. As well as gaining experience, shersquos stacked up additional qualications and learned how to cater formal occasions. ldquoThere arenrsquot a lot of jobs on offer in East Ayrshire, she says. ldquoWhen Dumfries Houses started up it was an excellent opportunity for young people.Kris Muir, , came as an unemployed painter and decorator on a Princersquos Trust joinery course four years ago, but now the single dad has is a qualied head gardener. He tends the five acre arboretum, recently planted with  native species of tree. ldquoThis got me off the sofa, he says. ldquoI used to think a plant was just a plant, Now he knows the Latin names of  plants. ldquoThis place has lted New Cumnock, ldquo he adds. ldquoThe hotels have started to fill up, and with fancier customers. One of them has had to be upgraded.Traditional building skills are an known enthusiasm of the current owner, but they are in demand, according to Michael Goodger, built environment education manager. ldquoThere are six million traditional buildings in the UK, most of which work on fundamentally dferent principles to modern day construction, he says. People living in traditional tenements make this mistake, he adds. ldquoModern gypsum doesnrsquot control moisture in the same way as lime plaster. Doing modern things to old buildings can have catastrophic effects.Now the Princersquos project has extended beyond the bounds of the Dumfries House estate for the first time with the refurbishment of the Town Hall and pool in New Cumnock. There is a new sense of optimism amid the faded bunting and boarded up shops. lsquoLido touristsrsquo come from as far away as London while locals of all ages flock to open air aquarobics and summer night-swimming sessions.Mary, back now as duty officer, makes sure they are looked after . What Prince Charles has done for the town has been ldquoamazing, she says.ldquoOnce you swim in outdoor pool you will always swim in an outdoor pool. You canrsquot beat it, she adds.

title: tories-select-brexit-campaign-boss-for-holyrood-seat
story: Braden Davy, the assistant director of the Scottish Vote Leave campaign, has been selected by local party members to fight the Angus North and Mearns constituency at the next Scottish Parliament election in .He defeated the Scottish Toriesrsquo chief whip Maurice Golden, who is a list MSP for the West of Scotland.The North Angus and Mearns seat is currently held by SNP rural affairs minister Mairi Gougeon, who won it in  with a majority of , over the Conservatives.However a year later, the overlapping Westminster seat of Angus, which had been SNP-held since its creation in , was won by Tory Kirstene Hair in the blue wave that swept over the North East.:Ruth Davidson branded shameless over Brexit flip-flopMr Davy said of his selection: ldquoI think being a Brexiteer helped.ldquoA large majority of our members voted Leave, and wanted someone who is a local councillor who lives in the constituency and shares their belief in Brexit.Despite previously working for MP Ross Thomson, Boris Johnsonrsquos Scottish campaign manager, Mr Davy said he was still ldquoon the fence in the Tory leadership contest.He said: ldquoIrsquom waiting until I see their performance at the Scottish Hustings [on July ].ldquoIrsquoll be basing it on who is going to defend the Union, has a good policy , and will deliver Brexit.Mr Davy, , a former McDonaldrsquos worker from Northumberlands, was previously a Scottish Labour candidate, standing against Alex Salmond in Gordon at the  election.He defected to the Tories after the EU vote, saying Labour was ldquoweak on independence and its attitude was ldquobelittling and patronising.:Labour candidate defects to Tories over partys "weak" stance on independenceIn , he was elected a Tory councillor for Forfar on Angus council.An SNP spokesperson said: ldquoThis is yet another embarrassment for Ruth Davidson, and shows whatever authority she may have had is quickly ebbing away.ldquoAs much as she tries to distance herself from her toxic colleagues, itrsquos clear the Tories are still pandering to the will of hard-line Brexiteers and preparing to sell out Scotland.In another internal selection fight, Lothians list MSP Gordon Lindhurst saw off a challenge from Holyrood colleague Miles Briggs for the Tory candidacy in the SNP-held Edinburgh Pentlands constituency.Mr Lindhurst contested the seat in , while Mr Briggs stood in neighbouring Edinburgh Southern.Edinburgh Southern is currently one of Labourrsquos few winnable seats in Scotland thanks to the formidable campaign machine built by Ian Murray, the MP title: richard-leonard-ally-voters-see-us-as-unfit-to-govern
story: Siobhan McCready, a member of the partyrsquos ruling executive committee, said members ldquoneed to park egos and personal ambitions, itrsquos time to stop the games and manoeuvring.She also questionedthere was enough talent among Labour MSPs and the shadow cabinet at Holyrood.Calling them a ldquodiminished parliamentary presence, she suggested drafting in trade unionists, councillors and senior activists ldquoto help sharpen the message.She said: ldquoItrsquos time to do things dferently, holding on and hoping for a change in wind direction whilst shuffling chairs isnrsquot enough.The partyrsquos electoral decline meant ldquotherersquos nothing to lose right now.The criticism coincided with a row over Scottish Labour ldquodesperately over-stating its achievements, after it claimed in a press release that it had ldquoled Parliament in voting to scrap Primary  standardised tests.However the vote it cited had been initiated by the Tories, who said Labour was ldquosimply making things up in the hope of challenging their current irrelevancy.Labour said that ithadnrsquot voted for the Tory motion it would have fallen, and said its record ldquoobviously rattled the SNP and Tories.Ms McCready, secretary of the Campaign for Socialism and chair of the Unite Scotland political committee, makes her comments ldquoin a personal capacity in the new issue of the Scottish Left review.She stressed she remained a supporter of Mr Leonard, but said isions, stale internal debates and tired practices are causing problems.She said: ldquoThe near wipe-out of Labour in Scotland has been a sobering experience. We are in uncharted waters, itrsquos unsettling, scary at times.ldquoHow did it come to this  Who is to blame  Why do the electorate not hear   understand   believe   trust our message  Why do others in the Party not get the message  What is that message  No matter what wing of the Party you identy with, the questions tend to be the same. Only the people to blame change.ldquoItrsquos frankly a waste of energy and just says to the electorate that we are a squabbling rabble, unfit to govern. At times, they are entirely right to hold that view!She also said Scottish Labourrsquos result in last monthrsquos European elections, in which it lost both its MEPs and fell to a single figure vote share, was ldquoas bad as it gets.But a change in collective will was needed, not a change of leader.She said: ldquoThe message didnrsquot cut through, nobody really knew what we stood for in the end - not even ourselves. It was a salutary lesson on the dangers of trying to keep everyone happy. In the end, no one really was.ldquoRichard for his part followed the policy as agreed by the membership, but it was a dficult sell in the face of a hostile media, confused electorate and, frankly, our own malcontents seemingly happy to capitalise on this for whatever their agendas are.ldquoIt was always going to be bad, but even the dire predictions were better than the eventual outcome. It was as bad as it gets.Calling for a change of collective will rather than a change of leader, she said: ldquoWe need to spend less time at Holyrood, where we simply arenrsquot getting a hearing, and much more time out in our communities talking about our vision, highlighting SNP failures and offering fresh ideas. Therersquos nothing to lose right now.Despite her declared support for Mr Leonard, Ms McCready also included a coded dig at his obsession with Labour history, which he often digresses into in speeches.She said voters to see more leadership and ldquoless about what Labour did in the past and more what it offers now. Yes, we have a proud history but the electorate want to hear what an invigorated Labour Party will do for them now.

title: scottish-tornado-chasers-travel-to-us-to-chase-the-weather
story: But after half a decade of visiting Kansas in the US to search for super-storms and ing without a scratch, Mrs Simpson decided she could relax.So much, in fact, that she thought it would be time to take a trip herself to the US to see one of naturersquos most impressive shows herself.But twisters are nothingnot unpredictable, and this year Mr Simpsonrsquos luck ran out when a stealthy cyclone formed next to the minibus he and his we were travelling in.The huge winds effortlessly lted the vehicle from the road and threw it into a field before dying down and vanishing almost as suddenly.Luckily, the passengers escaped with only broken bones, and a new-found respect for the power of the elements.The couple, from Brookfield in Renfrewshire, have now ed home with a tale to tell of one of naturersquos most destructive forces.Frances braves the stormMr Simpson, said: ldquoI just got interested in the idea of tornado chasing and itrsquos a real adrenaline rush when you see one. The power of these things is incredible.ldquoBut it always looked more dangerous than it actually is. Frances was always a bit against me going but nothing ever happened.ldquoSo I asked hershe wanted to come along and see it for herself, and she decided to try it out.Tornadoes are violently rotating columns of wind and cloud that descend from the sky to the ground, usually from spectacular thunderstorms.Windspeeds inside y between mph up to mph, and they can be anything in size from a few feet across to nearly a mile wide.Trying to find them and observe their movements in Americarsquos ldquoTornado Alley in the southeast states has sparked the hobby of tornado chasing, both for scientic research and for the experience, and guided tours have sprung up catering to the likes of Mr and Mrs Simpson.The trip the couple, who have two grown-up daughters, were on was run professionally. But all the trips come with the risk of encountering more weather than the tourists bargained for.Tornados are spectacular...... and are sometimes accompanied by lightningTornadoes can form at a momentrsquos notice, taking even the most experienced chaser off-guard.Mr Simpson said: ldquoWe were in a convoy of vans chasing a huge tornado, which was way ahead of us, and the rain was beating down on the van. Suddenly, the shout went up that there was a tornado off to ourright.ldquoIt was what they call a lsquorain-wrappedrsquo tornado ndash one thatrsquos been hidden by the storm and is impossible to see forming.ldquoIt just popped right down from the sky about  feet from the van and that was that. All hell broke loose.Mr Simpson said that he saw the back wheels of the van in front got lted by the wind before being settled down again. Then the twister hit his own vehicle.Because of the incredibly localised nature of a tornadorsquos winds, the couplersquos minibus was the only one turned over.He said: ldquoThe vanjust got lted up like it was nothing and was thrown across the road where it tipped over and rolled into a ditch.ldquoWhen it started rolling I just calmly thought lsquothis is the endrsquo, but it was over very fast. It was like being in a tumble dryer with all the luggage and people in the van being thrown about.ldquoIt seemed to last for about  minutes, but was over in a few seconds. It was very quiet when we came to a stop, except for the rain hammering off the bus. That sounded like a waterfall.The van ended in a ditchA tour guide was able to get the back door of the minibus open, and helped those inside to evacuate.Of the  people onboard the minibus when it overturned,  had to go to hospital for treatment, but there were no injuries other than broken bones.Mr Simpson suffered a broken collarbone and Mrs Simpson a fractured kneecap during the accident. Emergency services who attended said that the group had probably been saved from more serious harm because the ground was soft and saturated with rain from the storm.Mrs Simpson said: ldquoI was just glad to get out alive, and it could have been much worse, so wersquore very grateful for that. But, really, it was just one of those things and it was an experience, to say the least.She joked that her daughtersrsquo reaction ndash once they got over the shock of hearing their parentsrsquo bus had been struck by a tornado ndash has been one of utter dismay.The couple have ed home safe and soundThe mother-of-two said: ldquoThey are a utterly appalled at their mum and dad going off to chase tornadoes. They tell us wersquore not allowed out without carers anymore.Mr Simpson has already signed up for next yearrsquos tour, but his we is hanging up her tornado-chasing kit after deciding once was enough. Askedshe intends to join her husband in his next adventure, she replied with a flat ldquoNo way.However, Mr Simpson said he is looking forward to his next brush with Americarsquos biggest storms, although hopefully at a greater distance.He said: ldquoThey really are incredible. Just an absolutely majestic sight. The lightning that sometimes accompanies them is nothing like what we see here. Once yoursquove seen one of these tornadoes, Scotlandrsquos weather seems a little tame by comparison.Tornado Pics: Alan Simpson. Portrait: Kirsty Anderson The Herald

title: theresa-may-promises-greener-aid-spending-in-bid-to-tackle-climate-change
story: The Prime Minister will lead a session on climate change at the G summit in Osaka, calling on her counterparts to set their own net zero targets because the crisis requires an international response.She will also lobby leaders as part of the UKrsquos bid to host the next international climate conference.In an effort to show her commitment to the green agenda, Mrs May has committed that UK aid spending will be aligned with the conditions of the Paris climate change agreement.Officials said that would mean that when roads or energy infrastructure are funded from the aid budget, the UK will consider the greenest way to do this and use the best materials and design to manage the impacts of climate change.In her message to world leaders, Mrs May is expected to say: ldquoThe facts, which are clear, should guide us: we are running out of time to act.ldquoWe need a five-fold increase on existing  commitments to remain below . degrees of warming.ldquoIn addition to stronger national commitments, we need determined implementation, and a change in how we invest.ldquoAnd we need to build resilience, both in our own societies and economies, and in the most vulnerable countries.ldquoSo I urge everyone here to push for ambition and consider setting their own net zero targets.Mrs May has committed the UK to reach net zero by , a target now written into law.The UK is bidding in partnership with Italy to host the COP climate summit in , a major gathering expected to attract up , delegates including  world leaders.Turkey has a rival bid to host the summit and Mrs May will meet the countryrsquos president Recep Tayyep Erdogan on the margins of the G on Saturday.Mrs Mayrsquos Government has said it has the advantage because the UK has the worldrsquos most concentrated grouping of scientic, civil society and business expertise on climate change that would help develop the programme and objectives for the summit.Setting out the UKrsquos position, Mrs May will tell the G: ldquoThese next few years are critical. This is why tackling this crisis has become such a high priority for the UK.ldquoAnd it is why we have offered to preside over COP, in partnership with Italy.ldquoAs the first real test of our collective commitment at Paris to continually scale-up our emission reduction efforts over time, COP will be a critical moment.ldquoWe will need to see both a signicant ramping up in our existing medium term targets at the country level, and credible plans for what we are doing now to meet existing targets.ldquoOur citizens ndash and our youth in particular, whose lives will be shaped immeasurably by climate change ndash demand action. We will be judged by history on how we act in the next few years.Mrs May, who had a ldquoforthright exchange with Vladimir Putin on Friday, will have another controversial meeting on Saturday with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.A senior British official said the investigation into the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi would feature in the talks.ldquoIran will obviously figure .. and the Khashoggi investigation, the official said.

title: theresa-may-says-she-could-stay-on-as-mp-beyond-2022
story: The Prime Minister said she was looking forward to ing to the backbenches and devoting more time to her work as an MP for Maidenhead.She said she had not ruled out standing in the next election, due to take place in .The new Tory leader will be announced on July  and will take over as prime minister the following day.Mrs May said she still had not told husband Philip who she voted for in the contest to replace her.ldquoI havenrsquot been revealing to my husband who I have been voting for at every stage, she said.James Callaghan was the last ex-premier who stood at an election after leaving Downing Street.The former Labour premier fought the  election, four years after leaving Downing Street, while Ted Heath remained in the Commons until ,  years after losing the  election.David Cameron quit as an MP just two months after leaving Downing Street, while Gordon Brown did not seek re-election in  after Labour lost the  general election.Tony Blair left his Sedgefield seat at the same time as he quit Downing Street, while Margaret Thatcher retired from the Commons in  and took a seat in the Lords.Mrs May told reporters accompanying her on the visit to the G summit: ldquoIrsquom certainly going to be continuing as the MP for Maidenhead.ldquoIrsquom going to stay in Parliament and play my role by my own constituents.She added: ldquoIrsquom expecting the next election will be in  and I havenrsquot ruled out standing in that next election.Mrs May said it had been a ldquohuge privilege to be Prime Minister, itrsquos a huge honour, itrsquos a huge responsibility.She told ITV News: ldquoI am proud of the work that we have done in the UK and I look forward to ing to the backbenches andable to give my full time to my constituency.

title: joe-biden-defends-civil-rights-record-following-mauling-at-democratic-debate
story: Speaking to the Reverend Jesse Jacksonrsquos Rainbow Push Coalition, the white former vice president was working to repair the damage from a blistering attack from Calornia Senator Kamala Harris, the lone black woman in the  presidential race.During Thursdayrsquos presidential debate, Ms Harris criticised Mr Biden for recently highlighting his decades-old work with segregationist senators and his opposition to bussing school pupils during the s, creating a dramatic and deeply personal breakout moment.There was a little girl in Calornia who was bussed to school. That little girl was me. #DemDebate pic XKmxPMDHmdash Kamala HarrisJune , ldquoI heard, and I listened to, and I respect Senator Harris, Mr Biden said.ldquoBut we all know that  seconds to  seconds on a campaign debate exchange canrsquot do justice to a letime commitment to civil rights.Irsquove fought my heart out to ensure that civil rights, voting rights, and equal rights are enforced everywhere. These rights are not up to the states to decide. They are embedded in our Constitution. And the federal government has a duty to protect the civil rights of all people. pic vMqzRrgmdash Joe BidenJune , Mr Biden has surged to the top of the Democratic pack arguing that he is best positioned to defeat President Donald Trump because he can build a broad coalition of support.Appearances such as the one with Mr Jackson, his one-time rival in the  Democratic presidential primary, will signal whether Mr Harrisrsquo attack will chip into his support among African Americans.He acknowledged the critical role of black voters and labour unions on Friday, saying: ldquoYrsquoall are the ones that brung me to the dance.Mr Biden pushed back against some of Harrisrsquo specic criticisms, including her argument that he once opposed bussing, a measure intended to alleviate racial segregation.He said he was more opposed to federal intervention in bussing than the practice itself.ldquoI never, never, never, ever opposed voluntary bussing, Mr Biden said, adding that he supported federal legislation to ldquoaddress root causes of segregation in our schools and that he was always ldquoin favour of using federal authority to overcome state-initiated segregation, even in bygone days when it was not popular.But even while defending his own record, Mr Biden still tempted controversy.He said he envisioned a society in which everyone realises the ldquokid in the hoodie might be the next poet laureate and not a gang-banger.The ldquogang-banger remark was a reminder of his loose and undisciplined approach to language and a tendency to say things that he doesnrsquot think will offend his generation but that conjure very dferent images among others, especially young Americans.Calornia lawyer Tom McInerney signed up to be on Mr Bidenrsquos national finance team but said he notied the campaign this month that he was withdrawing his support.He pointed to what he called repeated missteps, including Mr Bidenrsquos comments on segregationists and the former vice presidentrsquos recent reversal on the Hyde Amendment, a long-standing congressional ban on using federal health care money to pay for abortions.I am in Japan at the G-, representing our Country well, but I heard it was not a good day for Sleepy Joe or Crazy Bernie. One is exhausted, the other is nuts ndash so whatrsquos the big deal mdash Donald J. TrumpJune , His reversal, he now says he opposes the amendment, came after rivals and womenrsquos rights group blasted him for affirming through campaign aides that he still supported the decades-old budget provision.ldquoI have tremendous respect for the vice president. However, I just became increasingly troubled by his comments, Mr McInerney said.ldquoIt just seems like he wasnrsquot thinking this through.Mr Bidenrsquos campaign offered no immediate comment on Mr McInerneyrsquos withdrawal.Also during Fridayrsquos event, Mr Biden leaned heavily on being Barack Obamarsquos vice president, something he did not do as much during the debate, when Ms Harrisrsquo relentless criticism often left him flustered and seemingly unsure of what to say.ldquoMy president gets much too little credit for all that he did. He was one of the great presidents of the United States of America, and Irsquom tired of hearing about what he didnrsquot do, Mr Biden said of Mr Obama.Sylvia Chapman, , of Chicago, attended Mr Bidenrsquos speech and said Thursdayrsquos confrontation between Ms Harris and Mr Biden was ldquojust a few minutes of talk.ldquoYou have to look at the whole picture, not just one chapter out of a book, said Ms Chapman, who is black and is the president of a union local in Chicago.She said she was undecided about who to support in , but Mr Biden is among the top of her choices, along with Senators Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Ms Harris.Patricia Ousley, , a black retired state employee from the Chicago suburb of South Holland, cheered loudly when Mr Biden told the crowd Mr Obama does not get the credit he deserves.She said Mr Bidenrsquos experience working alongside Mr Obama is a big reason she may support him in : ldquoI love that.

title: lgbtq-group-endorses-pete-buttigieg-for-president-in-2020-race
story: LGBTQ Victory Fund gave the gay -year-old mayor of South Bend, Indiana, its endorsement during a World Pride campaign event in New York on Friday.Victory Fund President Annise Parker said: ldquoMayor Petersquos candidacy is redefining what is possible in American politics.mdash Victory FundJune , Ms Parker said Mr Buttigiegrsquos experience as an Afghanistan War veteran and chief executive and his ldquoauthentic approach to politics make him ldquothe best candidate to defeat Donald Trump at the ballot box.The endorsement will provide a financial boost for Mr Buttigieg heading into Sundayrsquos second quarter fundraising deadline.The group gave two million US dollars to candidates in .Ms Parker says the Victory Fund will mobilise its network of supporters to help elect Mr Buttigieg.

title: monsters-skeletons-and-gods-reborn-as-images-revealed-for-scotlands-ray-harryhausen-show
story: Today the National Galleries of Scotland, and Harryhausens daughter Vanessa, are revealing the glimpses of several recently restored models.They include the models of the skeletons from Jason and the Argonautsand from his Sinbad series of the s and s, the Minotaur from Sinbad and the Eye of the Tiger,  and Medusa from Clash of the Titans .They will go on display next year at the Scottish National Gallery of Modern Artshow Ray Harryhausen: Titan of Cinema, which the galleries say with be "the largest and widest-ranging exhibition of Harryhausenrsquos work ever seen."The models will join newly restored and previously unseen material from Harryhausenrsquos collection and archive, from  May next year.The film director John Landis, writing for the  centenary celebrations, said: "The -year-old me was no longer sitting in my seat at the Crest Theater in West Los Angeles, I was on the beach of the island of Colossa and as awe-struck and fearful as Sinbad and his crew when the first Cyclops made his appearance....the th Voyage of Sinbad was a truly le-changing experience for me."Thrilled by the movie I went home and asked my mother, ldquoWho does that  Who makes the movie " She replied, ldquoWell a lot of people honey, but I guess the right answer is the Director.rsquo And that was that, I would be a Director when I grew up."Harryhausen, who died in , created stop motion animations that were used in films from s to s.As well as Jason and the Argonauts and the Sinbad series, his work included One Million Years B.C and Mighty Joe Young.Vanessa Harryhausen is currently writing a book to accompany next yearrsquos exhibition.Shesaid: ldquoOur plans to celebrate Dadrsquos centenary at the National Galleries in Edinburgh are so excitinghe was still around, he would be so enthused by all of our plans for ."Itrsquos wonderful that we are able to display so much of Dadrsquos collection: the space at the Galleries gives us great scope to display as many of his models and artworks as possible, as well as personal items which have never been exhibited before, such as his equipment and tools."We at the Ray and Diana Harryhausen Foundation are thrilled by the enthusiasm that the Galleriesrsquo team are showing about displaying Dadrsquos collection and celebrating his legacy."He established the Foundation in order to encourage future generations to enjoy stop-motion animation, and we hope that next yearrsquos activities in Edinburgh will encourage fans of all ages to be inspired by his creativity."We are thrilled to be working with Vanessa and The Ray and Diana Harryhausen Foundation on putting together the largest and most spectacular exhibition to date celebrating the le and work of Ray Harryhausen, titan of cinema.John Walsh, Filmmaker and Foundation Trustee said: ldquoToday Ray Harryhausen and his films have become cultural milestones."His technical achievements and his groundbreaking techniques pushed the medium of modern special effects forward and in doing so created his own genre."Only Walt Disney could be compared with such a seismic sht within the film industry. Bringing new audiences to his work and working practices is at the centre of the Foundationrsquos mission and the exhibition next year."

title: memorable-moments-in-scotlands-20-years-of-devolution
story: As MSPs worked to bring in new laws that changed day-to-day le for people across Scotland, some of the more offbeat moments at Holyrood include a future US president being called to give evidence on renewable energy.Sneaky cigars, a handwritten protest, structural issues in the debating chamber and a budget crisis also feature among some of the more notable incidents in the past  years.Donald Trump tells MSPs: lsquoI am the evidencersquoDonald Trump was just a tycoon embroiled in an ultimately unsuccessful battle against wind turbines being installed off the coast of his controversial golf resort in Aberdeenshire when he appeared before a Scottish Parliament committee in April .The now-US president was a witness at its inquiry into the Scottish Governmentrsquos renewable energy targets.Asked to point to evidence wind farms will destroy tourism, Mr Trump declared: ldquoI am the evidence. I am an expert in tourism, I am considered a world-class expert in tourism, so when you say lsquowhere is the evidence rsquo ndash I am the evidence.Rosie Kanersquos handwritten message of protest during the allegiance oathScottish Socialist Party MSPs were elected in May  on the promise of creating a Scottish Socialist republic so did not take kindly to being asked to pledge allegiance to the Queen at the formal swearing-in ceremony.As party colleagues protested via clenched fists and renditions of Rabbie Burns, SSP MSP Rosie Kane said she took the oath ldquounder protest, then, holding up her right arm, she opened the palm of her hand to reveal the message: ldquoMy oath is to the people.MSPs vote down the Scottish Parliament budgetHolyroodrsquos annual tax and spending plans have been voted down only once since devolution, when then-Finance Secretary John Swinneyrsquos budget suffered a shock defeat in .Labour, the Liberal Democrats and Greens joined together to oppose it, with only the Conservatives backing the Scottish Government.The vote was tied at  , with Presiding Officer Alex Fergusson using his casting vote, as per protocol, to maintain the status quo.Alex Salmond, then first minister, threatened to call an election, saying: ldquoThe Government canrsquot stay in office unless it can put the budget through.A revised budget was passed by  votes to two the following week as MSPs sought to avert a crisis.Safety scare as roof beam swings loose during chamber debateA ft long and ft thick wooden beam came out of one of its supporting sockets and swung loose, stopping just short of smashing into a glass  and dangling ft above the Conservative benches during a debate on the water industry in March .The immediate area was cleared and half an hour later business was suspended and the chamber was evacuated to enable structural engineers to assess the beam, which had been in place for just four years.It was later removed.MSPrsquos fly cigar on day no-smoking ban was pledgedLord Purvis of Tweed was simply Jeremy Purvis, a Liberal Democrat MSP, when he was spotted having a fly puff on a cigar out of a window in the no-smoking block at the Scottish Parliament on November  .It came on the same day the then First Minister Jack McConnell promised to ban smoking in enclosed public places in Scotland.At the time, Mr Purvis said: ldquoIt wasnrsquot in the office, it was out of a window in the MSP block hellip I shouldnrsquot have done it and I will not do it again.ldquoI have given an assurance to the parliamentary authorities.

title: theresa-may-tells-her-party-to-stick-to-traditional-tory-values
story: Either Boris Johnson or Jeremy Hunt will replace the Prime Minister on July  after the outcome of the Tory leadership contest.At the end of the G summit in Osaka, Mrs May offered her advice on how the Tories should combat the twin threats of the Brexit Party and the resurgent Liberal Democrats.ldquoI think whatrsquos important for the Conservative Party is that we continue as a party and as a Government in delivering on the values that have always underpinned what we as Conservatives believe in, she said.The next Conservative Leader will be the next Prime Minister.What ever matters most to you, make sure they know about it.Click here to tell the next Prime Minister what matters # https:t.co ffmhJnnbaU pic Wujprmdash ConservativesJune , ldquoThatrsquos about security, as much about economic security through a balanced approach to the economy, thatrsquos enabling us to end austerity.ldquoWe are seeing employment levels at a record high and itrsquos enabled us to bring our debt down, and our deficit down.ldquoWe also provide opportunity for people ndash you see that in what we have been doing for example in terms of the new T-Levelswe have been introducing ndash and giving people the freedom to actually be able to make decisions for themselves, and the freedom to spend more of their own money ndash  million people with tax cuts under a Conservative Government ndash Conservatives have been delivering for the people of the UK and will continue to do so.On the international stage, Mrs May suggested the UKrsquos success was linked to ldquocollaboration with other countries.Mrs May said: ldquoThis is my final G summit as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.ldquoWe have always understood that our success as a nation is tied to our collaboration with other countries and the relationships we build.ldquoAnd I have no doubt that Britain will retain the same strong spirit of international co-operation and compromise that has long characterised our engagement with the rest of the world.ldquoBecause this is the only way that we can protect and promote our interests and ensure the prosperity and security of our citizens for years to come.

title: queen-joins-msps-to-mark-20th-anniversary-of-scottish-parliament
story: The Prince of Wales, who holds the title of the Duke of Rothesay in Scotland, is accompanying his mother as she makes a speech to MSPs in the debating chamber.## Good morning everyone and welcome to live coverage of the ceremony celebrating  years of the Scottish Parliament. Feel free to ask us a question! You can also watch with BSL interpretation on https:t.co gDtoFFWw #scotparl https:t.co pSyWKFElowmdash Scottish ParliamentJune , The ceremony is taking place almost  years to the day since the Parliament officially assumed its legal powers on July ,  following devolution.Some of the young people born on that date are joining MSPs to take part in the event.Ahead of the Queenrsquos arrival, the Crown of Scotland was brought in a procession from Edinburgh Castle to Holyrood, carried by the Duke of Hamilton and accompanied by the Pipes and Drums of the st Battalion of the Scots Guards.The royal party arrived at the Scottish Parliament at around am, where they were met by Presiding Officer Ken Macintosh and representatives of the five parties at Holyrood.The Queen is to make an address at the ceremony, while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is also making a speech in response.Ms Sturgeon tweeted earlier: ldquoThis morning, we celebrate the th anniversary of the re-establishment of @ScotParl. In these two decades, the Parliament has become the democratic heart of our nation and delivered real progress. We now look towards a new decade and the next chapter in Scotlandrsquos story.At this morningrsquos event to mark the th anniversary of @ScotParl ndash and as we have done at all the Parliamentrsquos key milestones ndash @theSNP MSPs will wear Hugh MacDiarmidrsquos little white rose of Scotland. pic IauptHRxzmdash Nicola SturgeonJune , The chamber will also hear from Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson, Scottish Labourrsquos Richard Leonard, Scottish Green co-convener Patrick Harvie and Liberal Democrat MSP Tavish Scott.The speeches are being interspersed with cultural performances, including Scots Makar Jackie Kay reading her poem The Long View, written specially for the event and celebrating the changes in the  years since the Scottish Parliament was reconvened.With my @ScotTories colleagues celebrating #yearsscottishparliament pic AuJYqVmVUemdash Alison Harris MSPJune , All set for the th Anniversary of the Scottish Parliament. pic nVYzqWpKvmdash James Kelly MSPJune , The chamber choir of the National Youth Choir of Scotland, Scottish folk musician Phil Cunningham and members of Celtic band Capercaillie are also performing.Stuart MacMillan MSP will play Robert Burnsrsquos A Manrsquos A Man For Arsquo That on the bagpipes as the Queen leaves the chamber.After the ceremony, the Queen and Charles will attend a reception in the Parliamentrsquos main hall and sign the visitors book.When the Queenrsquos visit was first announced, Mr Macintosh said: ldquoSince the Scottish Parliament was established nearly two decades ago, Her Majesty the Queen has given us her unwavering support.ldquoShe addressed the newly elected MSPs in July  as we assumed our legislative powers and she has visited Holyrood many times since. Each time with messages of friendship and support. years since @ScotParl reconvened by my mother Winnie Ewing. Proud day. pic sipbPxIcmdash Annabelle EwingJune , ldquoIt will be a pleasure to welcome Her Majesty and HRH the Duke of Rothesay to the Parliament once again as we celebrate our th year.The visit marks the ninth time the Queen has addressed the Scottish Parliament.Her last speech to MSPs took place on July   as part of celebrations marking the opening of the fth session of the Parliament.Charles last visited the Parliament in  to attend a reception of the Princersquos Trust.The ceremony on Saturday is part of a year-long programme of events to mark two decades of devolution.

title: queen-hails-remarkable-scottish-parliament-while-visiting-msps
story: Two decades after she officially opened the first elected assembly in Edinburgh, the Queen said it was still ldquoat the centre of Scottish public le.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told how legislation passed at Holyrood had ldquomade Scotland a better place.The SNP leadersaid: ldquoAlthough this parliament is only  years young, it has long come of age.She added: ldquoThis parliament is firmly established as the centre of this nationrsquos public le. We have become the democratic institution which people look to, to reflect their priorities, values, hopes and dreams.This morning, we celebrate the th anniversary of the re-establishment of @ScotParl. In these two decades, the Parliament has become the democratic heart of our nation and delivered real progress. We now look towards a new decade and the next chapter in Scotlandrsquos story.mdash Nicola SturgeonJune , The Queen, accompanied by her son, the Prince of Wales ndash who is known in Scotland as the Duke of Rothesay ndash said she had ldquowatched Scotland grow and prosper over the last two decades.:Queen joins MSPs to mark th anniversary of Scottish ParliamentShe added: ldquoAs we look to the future, it is my sincere hope that this Parliament, and all those who come to serve in it, will use the power of this chamber to celebrate those invisible pillars of our communities, and follow their example by working tirelessly to improve peoplersquos lives, and strengthen the bonds of friendship and partnership both at home and abroad.Ahead of the Queenrsquos arrival, the Crown of Scotland was brought in a procession from Edinburgh Castle to Holyrood, carried by the Duke of Hamilton and accompanied by the Pipes and Drums of the st Battalion of the Scots Guards.Presiding Officer Ken Macintosh met the royal party, with the Queen then going on to greet Ms Sturgeon and senior figures from the other political parties at Holyrood.It was an honour to welcome Her Majesty The Queen to @ScotParl today as part of #ScotParl celebrations at Holyrood. KM pic FrvnVDwILSmdash PO Ken Macintosh MSPJune , Current and former MSPs were present, along with some of the Scots who were born on July   ndash the day the Scottish Parliament was officially opened.Mr Macintosh said over the last  years Holyrood had ldquogrown into a self confident institution.Mr Macintosh added: ldquoI am proud of that legislative record, but just as important is that the parliament itself has evolved to reflect the needs of the people we serve.:Memorable moments in Scotlandrsquos  years of devolutionAnd Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe  Acts this parliament has passed have ied in their impact. But from land reform in the first parliament to equal marriage in the last, to the Social Security Act in this, they have all made Scotland a better place.Thrilled to be @ScotParl th anniversary ceremony with some of the winners of our @YoungScot ldquoDear Scottish Parliamenthellip letters competition, which have been published in the ldquoScottish Parliament At  book # @KenMacintoshMSP #ScotParl @LettersOfNote @letterslive pic GkQoKJQmdash Louise MacdonaldJune , Scottish Secretary David Mundell, who was one of the MSPs elected  years ago, watched proceedings from Holyroodrsquos gallery.The MP said afterwards: ldquoThis is a really important day. I remember the opening ceremony so clearly and I remember, too, the sense of excitement that people right across Scotland shared at the opening of their new parliament.He added: ldquoAs a UK Government minister Irsquom proud to have played a role in delivering extra powers following the Calman Commission and, more recently, the Smith Commission.ldquoThrough the Scotland Acts, we have made Holyrood one of the most powerful devolved parliaments in the world.Holyrood is well-equipped to face the next  years.

title: aberdeenshire dancers head to holyrood
story: A collection of Aberdeenshire#s finest Highland Dancers are heading to the Scottish Parliament to help celebrate its th Anniversary.The dancers will help entertain guests in a fun-filled day at Holyrood on Saturday, June .A whole host of activities will take place on the day including live music and dance, retro games, and a rare opportunity to go behind the scenes of the Parliament and sit in the Presiding Officer’s seat.Sessions will be hosted on ‘The Future of Scotland’ where guests can remotely control robots of the future, experience D Holograms, or discuss their aspirations for Scotland for the next  years.There will also be  debates, including a Festival of Politics session which discusses the concept of ‘Happiness’.Looking ahead to the event, the Parliament’s Presiding Officer, the Rt Hon Ken Macintosh MSP said: “Our focus has always been for this Parliament to be open and accessible for all and what better opportunity to open our doors than for our th Anniversary celebrations.“There truly is something for everyone as we celebrate our birthday and play host to the best of Scottish culture."data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.mearnsleader webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The asset transfer bid for the mill is facing refusal"  Mill asset transfer facing refusal viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "MEAR | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "MEAR | Article Teaser"

title: entries open for competition
story: Entry forms are now available for the Inverurie Best Garden Competition .The showcase annual event, organised by the Inverurie Environmental Improvement Group, is now in its th year.The nine Best Garden categories are small front garden large front garden, hanging basket or container sheltered housing or retirement home low-maintenance garden fruit and vegetable garden business premises non-commercial premises and place of worship.There will also be a discretionary award for the most improved garden or for a garden that has been brought back to le.John Glover, IEI chairperson, said: “Gardening is rewarding on so many dferent levels as it is a relaxing hobby that can be enjoyed by people of all age groups. “This is an excellent opportunity for the local community to get involved in making the town look vibrant, whilst receiving the praise and recognition they deserve for their efforts in maintaining wonderful front gardens.“The aim of the Inverurie Best Garden Competition is to draw attention to the contribution that Inverurie gardeners make to the visual quality of the town and to encourage others to do the same”. title: inverurie firm to host charity event
story: Just a few tickets remain for a fundraising event in aid of Charlie House#s Big Build Appeal which will take place in Inverurie on Friday .During , Inverurie-based asset cleaning and decontamination solutions specialist company Denholm MacNamee has pledged to raise £, in support of the Charlie House Big Build Appeal.The aim of the appeal is to raise funds to build a state-of-the-art specialist support centre that will provide a wide range of services to babies, children and young people with complex disabilities and le-limiting conditions, and their families, in the North East of Scotland.The total raised by the company so far is expected to take a major step forward on Friday when Inverurie’s Drouthy Laird is the setting for a quiz night and disco.Teams of up to six are invited to enter at a cost of £ per person.The evening will also feature a raffle and two auctions – one of which will benefit Denholm MacNamee’s parent organisation’s concurrent fundraising campaign on behalf of Glasgow’s Royal Hospital for Children.Top prizes in the raffle include a Hugo Boss watch donated by Sinclairs, £ courtesy of Logie Country House and a £ voucher for Slaters. Among the lots on offer in the busy silent auction are a signed Aberdeen Football Club shirt from Donside Frames, signed Jake La Motta “Raging Bull” boxing shorts donated by Tony Read and a signed Celtic FC football which has been gted by the club.Commenting on preparations for the evening, Julie McAdams of Denholm MacNamee said: “We are incredibly grateful to the many, many companies and iniduals who have so generously supported this event. title: stagecoach supports armed forces day
story: Stagecoach North Scotland is helping to support Armed Forces Day .Armed Forces Day, on Saturday, June , is a chance for the public to show support for the men and women who make up the Armed Forces community: from currently serving troops to Service families, veterans and cadets.Stagecoach North Scotland is offering free travel, in advance and on the day itself, to armed forces personnel wearing their unorm, carrying a military ID card and veterans carrying a veteran’s badge.With the Armed Forces Day Parade in Aberdeen it is hoped that personnel will take up the offer to travel by bus to the event in the city centre. Managing Director, Stagecoach North Scotland, David Liston said: “We are sending a clear and proud message to armed forces communities across the North Scotland area that we appreciate them and are grateful for everything they do.
